title: 3.1: Basic Forces and Physics
summary: Learn to apply forces like gravity to particles using UpdateDirectionBlock
intro: In this lesson, you'll learn how to apply forces to particles, such as gravity. We'll use UpdateDirectionBlock to modify particle direction over time, and combine it with delta time to create realistic physics-based movement.
steps: Create a <filter-value>System</filter-value> block - this is the root of your particle system
Add a <filter-value>Texture</filter-value> block to provide a texture for the particles and connect to System block
Load a <textures>flare.png</textures> by load button in the Texture block properties
Add a <filter-value>CreateParticle</filter-value> block to emit particles and connect to System block
Add a <filter-value>Color4</filter-value> block and set its value to a base color
Connect the Color4 block's output to CreateParticle block's color input
Add a <filter-value>Float</filter-value> block and set its value for base size
Connect the Float block's output to CreateParticle block's size input
Add a <filter-value>SphereShape</filter-value> block to emit particles from a sphere volume and connect between CreateParticle and System blocks
Add an <filter-value>UpdateDirection</filter-value> block to modify particle direction and connect between SphereShape and System blocks
Add a <filter-value>Direction</filter-value> block to get the current direction
Add a <filter-value>Delta</filter-value> block to get delta time
Add a <filter-value>Converter</filter-value> block to create a gravity vector (0, -9.8, 0 for downward gravity)
Add a <filter-value>Float</filter-value> block with value 0 for X, another with value -9.8 for Y, and another with value 0 for Z
Connect the Float blocks to Converter block's X, Y, and Z inputs respectively
Add a math <filter-value>Multiply</filter-value> block to multiply gravity by delta time
Connect the Converter block's Vector3 output to Multiply block's left input and Delta block to right input
Add a math <filter-value>Add</filter-value> block to add gravity delta to current direction
Connect Direction block to Add block's left input and Multiply block's result to right input
Connect the result from Add block to UpdateDirection block's direction input
Add an <filter-value>UpdatePosition</filter-value> block after UpdateDirection block and connect between UpdateDirection and System blocks
Add an <filter-value>UpdateColor</filter-value> block after UpdatePosition block and connect between UpdatePosition and System blocks
Add an <filter-value>UpdateSize</filter-value> block after UpdateColor block and connect between UpdateColor and System blocks

blocks.name: Update Direction Block
blocks.description: Updates the direction of particles each frame. This is essential for applying forces like gravity, wind, or other directional effects. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and configure its properties in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Name
properties.description: The display name of the block. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

properties.name: Direction
properties.description: The new direction vector to apply to the particle. Can be calculated from current direction plus forces. Connect a Vector3 output to this input.

blocks.name: Input Block (Direction)
blocks.description: Retrieves the current direction of a particle. Direction represents the velocity vector of the particle. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and set its contextual value to Direction in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Contextual Value
properties.description: The type of contextual data - Direction in this case. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

blocks.name: Input Block (Delta)
blocks.description: Retrieves the delta time from the system. Delta time is the time elapsed since the last frame, essential for frame-rate independent physics calculations. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and set its system source to Delta in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: System Source
properties.description: The system source - Delta for delta time. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

blocks.name: Converter Block
blocks.description: Creates Vector3 from individual X, Y, Z float values. Used to construct the gravity vector (0, -9.8, 0). In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and configure its properties in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Inputs (X, Y, Z)
properties.description: Individual float inputs for X, Y, Z components. Connect Float blocks to these inputs.

properties.name: Vector3 Output
properties.description: The combined Vector3 output. Use this output when creating 3D vectors.

blocks.name: Math Block (Multiply)
blocks.description: Multiplies two values. Used to multiply gravity by delta time, ensuring physics calculations are frame-rate independent. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and set its operation to Multiply in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Operation
properties.description: The mathematical operation - Multiply. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

blocks.name: Math Block (Add)
blocks.description: Adds two Vector3 values. Used to add gravity acceleration to the current direction vector. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and set its operation to Add in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Operation
properties.description: The mathematical operation - Add. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

blocks.name: Sphere Shape Block
blocks.description: Emits particles from a sphere volume. Used in this lesson to create particles that fall due to gravity. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and configure its properties in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Name
properties.description: The display name of the emitter. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

codeCopy: This lesson demonstrates how to apply forces to particles. The key concept is that forces modify direction over time. We multiply the force (gravity) by delta time to ensure the effect is consistent regardless of frame rate. The formula is: newDirection = currentDirection + (force * deltaTime). This creates realistic physics-based movement where particles accelerate downward due to gravity.
objectives: Understand how Update Direction block modifies particle velocity
Apply gravity force to particles using vector math
Use delta time for frame-rate independent physics
Combine forces with current direction to create acceleration
Understand the relationship between force, direction, and position

commonMistakes.mistake: Forgetting to multiply force by delta time
commonMistakes.explanation: Without delta time, physics will be frame-rate dependent. Particles will move faster on slower computers and slower on faster computers.
commonMistakes.solution: Always multiply forces by delta time: force * deltaTime. This ensures consistent behavior regardless of frame rate.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using position instead of direction for forces
commonMistakes.explanation: Forces modify direction (velocity), not position directly. Position is updated based on direction.
commonMistakes.solution: Apply forces to Update Direction block, not Update Position block. The chain should be: Update Direction â†’ Update Position. Connect blocks in this order in the editor.

commonMistakes.explanation: In most 3D coordinate systems, Y is up, so downward gravity should have a negative Y value.
commonMistakes.solution: Use negative Y for downward gravity: (0, -9.8, 0). Positive Y creates upward force.

homework: Try changing the gravity Y value to see how it affects particle fall speed
Create upward gravity by setting gravity Y to a positive value
Add horizontal forces by modifying gravity X or Z
Try combining multiple forces by adding more math operations
